title: I'm a new dad and homeowner. So, which costs more – nursery fees or my mortgage?
text:
Until I had a child I thought buying a flat in London was the most efficient way of testing my patience and emptying my bank account.

Now, like more seasoned parents, I realise that the accolade belongs to childcare. Strict rules around child-to-nursery worker ratios and mountains of compliance paperwork have pushed costs to ludicrous levels.

British nursery fees as a proportion of the average salary are by far the highest among the 35 members of the OECD, an international economic body. In some parts of England, sending a child to nursery for 25 hours a week costs the same as university tuition, according to a study by the Coram Family and Childcare Trust.

Sending my little fella for three days...
